title: Do you think gaming consoles will disappear in the future? - Quora

response.answer_text: No, not in the foreseeable future at least. This is PC gaming:  And this is console gaming:  Which is better, a PC or a console? A PC, no doubt. It has more power and versatility. Anything you can play on a console, you can play on a PC at least just as well (apart from some console-exclusive games), while many games and entire genres are very uncomfortable or downright impossible to play on a console. Besides, most people own a PC for serious, non-gaming purposes anyway, so why bother buying a separate machine just for gaming? Because that’s not the point. The question here is not what you play. The question is where, when, why and how you play. A lot of people play mobile games. Why? Mobile games are simplistic to the point of boring. They’re good for burning five minutes of your life, not much else. Why would you play Candy Crush, when you can play Civilization VI instead? Because you play mobile games when you can’t play PC games. They’re meant to help you pass the time when you’re sitting away from home and waiting for something, like the bus, the class to start, or your spouse from a shoe store. And they do that perfectly. They’re very good at filling their niche.  Ignoring the actual game, what happens, when you play on a computer? You might have a separate study/work room where the computer is, or at least it’s placed in a quiet corner, so that you can concentrate on your work without anything or anyone breaking your flow. When you sit in front of the PC to play, it’s time to play. You can sit there for several hours with your back turned to the center of the room and the rest of your family. You don’t look over your shoulders or say a single word to anyone, except maybe your teammates on Discord. You further isolate yourself by putting on headphones and dimming the lights. When you sit at a computer, your mindset subconsciously switches to work mode. You’re there to finish tasks and get jobs done, even if those tasks and jobs are to have fun and relax. Figuring out complex mechanics is not a chore, it’s a part of the fun. Reading several pages’ worth of text dialogue doesn’t subtract from the fun, because you want to be immersed in the lore of the game universe. PC gaming has taken its place as a serious and goal-oriented pastime. Console gaming is the opposite of that. You go to the living room, turn on the TV and the console, get comfortable on the sofa, and start having some mindless and action-oriented fun. Your family is there talking with you and maybe even playing with you. They can even watch your play just like watching TV. Everyone can see and hear you. You don’t shut anyone out, you bring them all in (whether they like it or not). Sitting quietly reading text or planning your next move doesn’t mix well with this kind of gameplay, action is better. Console gaming is increasingly taking its place as a casual and socially oriented pastime. As you can see from the pictures I posted, goal-oriented activities and socially oriented activities have existed in human behavior for thousands of years without competing with each other. Original question: “Do you think gaming consoles will disappear in the future?“ Eventually, certainly. But it won’t happen because some other gaming platform is better. It will happen when people invent a new, even more entertaining and immersive way to have fun with their friends and family in their living rooms. I don’t see that happening very soon. On the contrary, console gaming can only be expected to rise in popularity, as parents start accepting that games are not just for kids anymore.

Of course. Once technology catches up and makes it possible to stream video without noticeable lag, consoles will be a thing of the past. I’m sure most of the major manufacturers are fearing this eventual day and probably doing anything they can to slow the process… Regardless, there will be a disruption on the horizon that will offer a service where you’ll be able to play whatever you want, where ever you are with a cell phone connection and minimal lag and no hardware purchase needed. Hardware costs are a huge drain on console creators. You have to spend all that time designing a new(ish) console that is already outdated by the time it’s actually produced. Then they have to wrangle game studios into making games for the platform. This all costs huge amounts of revenue, usually at a loss I might add. Sony PlayStation 2 comes to mind, where Sony was basically giving away the platform, hoping to recoup the money on software purchases. It worked for them for a while, but it goes to show how far they have to go to turn a profit on hardware. Noticeably, Hardware updates/re-imagines itself with a pretty steady timeline, meaning by the time a console is reaching it’s prime, it’s already 3 to 5 generations behind in GPU power. Unless console makes adopt a more PC geared platform, where you can update your GPU/Mobo/Memory whenever you’d like, there will always be issues with sealed consoles. Once one of the big 3 buys up or agrees to work with the company with the disrupting tech, they might embrace it and it grow from there, but honestly, I don’t see that happening. They all have vested interests in keeping this cycle going for as long as possible to bilk the public into buying into their specific eco-system. Nintendo (All that 1980’s money) is about the only company that comes to mind that could keep a steady course with console’s and last the longest, but even Nintendo would have to see the profit to be made if someone offers them a platform to sell their software where it’s mutually beneficial.. Mario Run and Pokemon Go are perfect examples.

I doubt that will happen. Being a PC gamer most of my life, I have never been too much a fan of consoles. However, with many PC games becoming more console-like in operation, and even one of the main bragging rights of the PC - the First Person Shooter - getting proper console versions, I do not see the console leaving us any time (soon, at least). The only bastion for PC gaming seems to be RTS - I’ve tried it on console, and it sucked. However, with controllers getting more advanced (is there a multi-function programmable controller out already? If not, I believe there will be one soon… Oh, it’s called the Steam controller)… well, I do not want it, but I could rather foresee PC gaming going the way of the Dodo and consoles taking over. I also foresee that in time, the GPU will be an add-on to the CPU itself, not the motherboard; and the sound card going completely external (much like the Creative Extigy started it). It might even be that there will be no more graphics CARDS sold, but graphics UNITS: and external unit connected to the computer, that does the graphics processing. Much like the external graphics card mount that Mac users have. In fact, I foresee the PC to, in time, become a modular console: instead of cards added to the inside on a singular motherboard, the mobo itself will be basically just the CPU and RAM connectors, and all else connect to it on the outside. Mac Mini, anyone? Raspberry Pi? You can already put an entire computer on a board roughly the size of a credit card - only the quest for more condensed pixels, keeps the motherboard alive.

Do you ever wonder how gaming consoles came into existence? Initially, when games were invented, they used to play on CPUs. But due to heating, the CPU was not able to process these games which are how gaming consoles were invented.  Image Source: COGConnected Gaming consoles provided better pixel computation and reduced heating. That was the birth of gaming consoles. However, nowadays gaming consoles is not a necessity to play good quality games. Most people would rather play games on their phones or laptops rather than invest in a separate console only for gaming. In the current age, smart phones are embedded with advanced features to support online gaming. Even though gaming consoles are also getting advanced and better with time, the factor of heating up still remains a problem. Gaming consoles heat up when continuously fed with a lot of data and eventually damages the console. However in the future, with advancing technology, the problem of heating up will be solved with AI technology. However, nowadays, many gaming enthusiasts are sticking to online games on their laptops and computers. There are laptops specialized only for gaming. Gaming console companies like Xbox are creating versions of their games that can be played on laptops and phones. Play Station has created its PlayStation Now that’s allows players to stream PlayStation games on their phones and laptops. Personally, I do believe that gaming consoles are on their slow route to retirement.

Maybe, maybe not. Looking at the biggest three: Playstation PS1 sales: 102 million PS2 sales: 155 million PS3 sales: 87 million PS4 sales: 108 million Xbox Xbox sales: 24 million Xbox 360 sales: 84 million Xbox One sales: 50 million Nintendo N64 sales: 32 million Gamecube sales: 21 million Wii sales: 101 million Wii U sales: 13 million Switch sales: 52 million  The Nintendo sales tell us everything we need to know about what consoles need to be to survive in the long term - innovative. PC gaming has come on in leaps and bounds since the PS2’s heyday, and it’s also much more accessible price-wise. Consoles can’t just get by on the fact that they’re powerful and game-orientated at a low price point nowadays, they need to offer more. The Wii went down a storm because despite not being at all powerful, the wireless interactive controller was innovative.  In my opinion, sales of the next generation consoles will decide their fate. It looks to me as if the overall sales trend is on the verge of tipping down into a slippery slope. If the PS5 and/or Series X come up with the goods, they might be able to buck this for a generation or two. We’ll see.

Yes, in the sense that consoles will just become small form factor computers. The industry has already made great strides to normalize the platform to simplify work for developers. XBOX now has the XBOX One X, which is analogous to the high end gamer PC. Also no, people will prefer the simplicity of having a gaming system (at lower cost) and laptops (for light computer work). Gaming is also moving toward a remote access model. The game content is streamed to your screen. We can expect as technology improves, this will be possible over the internet, and then the industry will shift to cloud services for video gaming. Consoles would then be simple way to connect your controller to your TV and to the cloud. There will always be a need for this service. EDIT: I just had the thought that TV’s already have internet. Perhaps we’ll skip the console and go directly to cloud gaming via Smart TV.

Personally, I would like PC to come back as the main gaming platform. I had a lot of consoles since PS1 and my gaming experience decayed a lot after the PS2. I mean, I had a lot of fun online with the Xbox 360, but now I got a gaming PC I regret not having done it earlier for a bunch of reasons, mostly being able to play older games like Half-Life or GTA San Andreas on Steam whenever I want, without Microsucks' bullshit backwards compatibility policies. But on the other hand, I think consoles are still going to be a thing for a while, mostly because their existence stabilizes a common ground for hardware specs, giving developers a much easier time deciding how heavy can their game be hardware-wise to be accessible to the general public. Consoles even help PC hardware not to rise in power too fast, making building a gaming PC less of a bet on how long will your hardware last until you have to upgrade.

Q: Are Consoles dying? Yes… they’re dying so hard that Microsoft has spent millions of dollars on a new console that can go toe-to-toe with a top-tier gaming PC (according to Digital Foundry[1], the internet’s foremost experts on all things related to gaming technology)                  To All The PC Master Race Folks: before you go typing out a massive rage dump screed about how a console can’t equal a PC, do us all a favor and check yourself - because all you’re gonna do is make yourself look foolish Digital Foundry has said (after they actually looked at all of the Series X internals before playing games on the machine) that the Series X is the equal of a gaming PC that would easily cost $1500 to build from scratch… and while you think of yourselves far too highly, you are not… I repeat NOT… more knowledgeable than Digital Foundry[2] - whose whole existence is geared towards understanding computer graphics tech (while yours is to sit around eating stale Cheetos in your mom’s basement) Footnotes[1] Digital Foundry - 4K gaming videos to remix & analyze.[2] Digital Foundry • Eurogamer.net

I doubt that anything man-made will survive the heat death of the universe, 100 trillion years from now. Oh, not that far in the future? How about a billion years in the future? A million? A thousand? Okay, let’s just look 100 years into the future. Even that short distance into the future, technological advances can’t be accurately predicted. After all, one hundred years ago, no one would have predicted there would be such a thing as a video game console. Even electric pinball machines didn’t come into existence until the 1930s. But if I were to guess, general computing power will eventually reach a point where there is no need to have specialized hardware to simulate the most realistic experiences detectable by human senses. And it may be that the need for physical input and output devices will become eliminated. so that we can experience entertainment with even more immersion.

I don't think so. Mobile gaming has grown recently, but I don't think it'll ever be more popular than console or PC gaming. I don't think phones or tablets will ever give a gamer the gaming experience that a console can. I would never want to play games like Skyrim, CS:GO, Battlefield 1, or other games like those on a small screen. And although the Nintendo Switch is a tablet, it still has a dock for playing on your TV, because Nintendo knows that no one wants to play BF1 on that small screen. It also lacks the power to run some games to their full potential. Maybe one day phones and tablets will be able to run games in 4k, with no frame rate issues, and have good controllers, but I will still like to play on a larger TV. I will still like to look at my book case full of games. And I will still like to see my gaming setup, complete with consoles and a PC.

Eventually, yes. People like convenience, and having multiple different consoles to play all your games as well as a computer and phone is not very convenient. In the future I see everyone having a single device that performs the functions of gaming, work and communication wherever they want. Currently this is not very functional because to get the portability of a laptop or mobile phone you need to cut on computing power. But once you can have all the performance you need in the size of something like a phone, larger devices like gaming consoles and desktop PCs will no longer be required by the average consumer.

Never. I say this for a number of reasons. One would be consoles have been around since the early 70's and are still very popular 47 years later. The second reason would be that most consoles are cheaper and have more exclusive games then a gaming PC has. And the third reason is: They are also gaming PC’s as well! That means as computer hardware improves, so will consoles. So all in all console gaming will more and likely never die out and remain a staple in most homes ether as a DVD player or just a computer in genral.

No. I love PC gaming and have been a PC gamer most of my life but it does come with it’s fair share of troubleshooting, having to clear our malware, viruses, dealing with keeping your HDD/SSD tidy and clear and many other small annoyances. You just don’t have to do any of that with a console. Also, buying a PC is a mixed bag - Quite often you need to know about PC’s or you will be sold a POS for £1000 that has a shitty GPU/PSU inside and will barely run games. Building a PC is great fun and learning but again - people don’t want to deal with that. Consoles are for most people, easy. Buy it, turn it on and it’ll work for 5–6 years. All you’re school friends are on it and you can play with them.

No way. First of all there is no PC replacement for portable consoles like the PS Vita, Switch and 3DS. Secondly, home consoles are way easier to setup than PCs and much cheaper for the same quality of gameplay since console games are much more optimized than PC games are. No driver issues, No random crashes etc that you often find on the PC. Thirdly, Nintendo will never license their games to a different platform. It took them decades to make Super Mario Go appear for mobile phones. Good luck getting them to bring their games to PC.

This is very tough question) Few years ago Microsoft company that created XboX console had to stop the production of the Kinect for xbox , explaining this by the fact that the sales are very low. From the other side sony playstation after that created their console with VR glasses as a new trend in gaming industry. So it is very difficult to tell if this is the end of console era or no , but while such giants of console gaming industry as Sony and Microsoft will be on the gaming field there will be a long lasting battle between them. Also you can get more interesting about the future video game consoles.

I know a couple strictly PC gamers . 90%+ play consoles. PC is surely better if you have all the right specs.. most can't be bothered with what specs they need. Changing settings..altering this and… NOPE.. Put it in and play. That's what we want. Consoles will never die.. not before me anyway.. If they do after me - I don't care btw.

I’d say in about 30–50 years we could see a vast change in audio visual entertainment. Just think about it; in the last 50 years, we’ve had PCs go from being the size of refrigerator to the smaller than a palm. Imagine how much it’ll advance now, especially with VR and AI technology getting a TON of funding right now. Although, I’m not too crazy about the auto-driving cars.

Google just announced that they’re releasing Stadia, and Intel and Nvidia are focusing more on supporting servers. If anything, I think it’s the personal computer that’s slowly being phased out in favor of a future where all the computing power and “proprietary software” (a.k.a. games) are hosted on super powerful streaming servers, while everyone would be playing only on consoles.

I don’t think video game consoles are becoming obsolete at all. Just compare each console with its predecessor, you will notice a ton of improvement. Heck, even PS4 Pro is a good improvement from Normal PS4.

No, some people will never be able to afford PCs and others just don’t want to deal with the headaches of pc gaming. There are many cons to PC gaming and along with the price the larger costs for a decent pc than a console, there will always be a causal console market.

Most of the gamers I know exclusively stick to consoles and consoles only, because of fears associated with PC. This question is clearly based on a false premise. The console video game industry grows because the consoles come from a trusted brand like Sony and Microsoft. Certain games like Sekiro, Halo and COD attract people to a console because they’re the games that customers want to play.
I’m not sure if they’ll ever be “obsolete” there is in most hobbies a “Starter Kit” And in the gaming hobby consoles will probably always fill this niche.
Yes, but only once people stop buying them and realize PC is the true master race.
No,they haven’t because online gaming or streaming services of gaming don’t mean that consoles have came to an end. Every platform has its priorities ,their pros and their cons.
New PC console was came last year, never obsolete.
No…
